bhtAttempts.bht: After the trial that took place late in the night, our Evangelist found evidence of a subsequent meeting of the Sanhedrim during the daytime, which is also mentioned in Matthew 27:1. This meeting of the elders, or the assembly of the elders, composed the Sanhedrin, made up of both Sadducees (chief priests) and Pharisees (scribes). It is important to note that according to Roman law and Jewish usage, final condemnation and investigation of capital crimes were not permitted during the night. Thus, this formal assembly, known as the presbyterion, gathered at the customary location in the temple.

The Gospel of Luke reveals that there was a continuation of the trial of Jesus carried out by the Sanhedrin during daylight hours after the initial trial that occurred at night. This subsequent meeting, known as the presbyterion or assembly of the elders, was composed of both Sadducees (chief priests) and Pharisees (scribes), who were nearly equally represented. It is worth noting that Roman law prohibited final condemnation before dawn, and Jewish tradition also forbade the investigation of capital crimes at night. The presbyterion gathered in their customary location within the temple to discuss the case.
